'''Corporate social responsibility''' ('''CSR''', also called '''corporate sustainability, sustainable business, corporate conscience''', '''corporate citizenship''' or '''responsible business''')<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wood |first=Donna J. |title=Corporate Social Performance Revisited|journal=The Academy of Management Review |year=1991 |volume=16 |issue=4 |pages=691–718 |doi=10.2307/258977 |jstor=258977}}</ref> is a type of international private business self-regulation.<ref name=":3"/> While once it was possible to describe CSR as an internal organisational policy or a [[business ethics|corporate ethic strategy]],<ref>{{cite web|author2= J. Dann|author1= N. Malhotra (of Stanford GSB)|url= https://www.cbsnews.com/news/business-ethics-integral-to-corporate-strategy-says-stanfords-malhotra|title= Business Ethics Integral to Corporate Strategy, says Stanford's Malhotra|date= Jul 1, 2009|website= cbsnews.com|language= en|access-date= Aug 14, 2018|quotation= [BNET:] Ethics as central to overall corporate strategy--is that conventional wisdom or is that a new approach? [Professor:] I think a lot of students think, "Ethics is a constraint on profits." A lot of corporate social responsibility is taught as a part of marketing.|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170318160806/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/business-ethics-integral-to-corporate-strategy-says-stanfords-malhotra|archive-date= March 18, 2017|deadurl= no}}</ref> that time has passed as various international laws have been developed and various organisations have used their authority to push it beyond individual or even industry-wide initiatives. While it has been considered a form of [[Industry self-regulation|corporate self-regulation]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sheehy|first=Benedict|date=2012|title=Understanding CSR: An Empirical Study of Private Regulation|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/journals/MonashULawRw/2012/16.pdf|journal=Monash University Law Review|volume=38|pages=103–127|via=}}</ref> for some time, over the last decade or so it has moved considerably from voluntary decisions at the level of individual organisations, to mandatory schemes at regional, national and even transnational levels.
Considered at the organisational level, CSR is an organisational policy. As such, it must align with and be integrated into a [[business model]] to be successful. With some models, a firm's implementation of CSR goes beyond compliance with regulatory requirements, and engages in "actions that appear to further some social good, beyond the interests of the firm and that which is required by law".<ref name=CPRtheory2001>{{cite journal|title=Corporate social responsibility: A theory of the firm perspective |first1=Abagail |last1=McWilliams |first2=Donald |last2=Siegel |year=2001 |journal=Academy of Management Review |volume=26 |issue=1 |pages=117–127 |doi=10.5465/amr.2001.4011987}}</ref><ref name=CSRinternational2005>{{cite journal | title=Corporate Social Responsibility: International Perspectives | first1=Abagail | last1=McWilliams | first2= Donald | last2=Siegel | first3=Patrick M. | last3=Wright | format=PDF | date=March 2006 | number=0604 | series=Working Papers | publisher=Department of Economics, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute | location=Troy, New York | url=http://www.economics.rpi.edu/workingpapers/rpi0604.pdf }}</ref> The choices of 'complying' with the law, failing to comply, and 'going beyond' are three distinct strategic organisational choices. While in many areas such as environmental or labor regulations, employers may choose to comply with the law, or go beyond the law, other organisations may choose to flout the law. These organisations are taking on clear legal risks. The nature of the legal risk, however, changes when attention is paid to [[soft law]].<ref>Klarsfeld, A., Delpuech, C. (2008). Hard law, soft law, weak law: the implications of the neo-institutional and social regulation theories on CSR and the distinction between hard and soft law, Working Paper, Toulouse Business School</ref> Soft law may incur legal liability particularly when businesses make misleading claims about their sustainability or other ethical credentials and practices. Overall, businesses may engage in CSR for strategic or ethical purposes. From a strategic perspective, the aim is to increase long-term profits and shareholder trust through positive public relations and high ethical standards to reduce business and legal risk by taking responsibility for corporate actions. CSR strategies encourage the company to make a positive impact on the environment and [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] including consumers, employees, investors, communities, and others.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Thomas |last=Farrington |first2=Ross |last2=Curran |first3=Keith |last3=Gori |first4=Kevin D. |last4=O'Gorman |first5=C. Jane |last5=Queenan |year=2017 |title=Corporate social responsibility: reviewed, rated, revised |url= http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/IJCHM-05-2015-0236 |journal=International Journal of Contemporary Hospitality Management |volume=29 |issue=1 |pages=30–47 |doi=10.1108/IJCHM-05-2015-0236 |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> From an ethical perspective, some businesses will adopt CSR policies and practices because of ethical beliefs of senior management. For example, a CEO may believe that harming the environment is ethically objectionable.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/09/19/patagonias-philosopher-king|title=Patagonia’s Philosopher-King|last=Paumgarten|first=Nick|date=2016-09-12|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-04-24|language=en|issn=0028-792X}}</ref>
Proponents argue that [[corporation]]s increase long-term profits by operating with a CSR perspective, while critics argue that CSR distracts from businesses' economic role. A 2000 study compared existing [[econometric]] studies of the relationship between social and financial performance, concluding that the contradictory results of previous studies reporting positive, negative, and neutral financial impact, were due to flawed [[empirical analysis]] and claimed when the study is properly specified, CSR has a neutral impact on financial outcomes.<ref name=CPRneutral2000>{{cite journal | title=Corporate social responsibility and financial performance: correlation or misspecification? | first1=Abagail | last1=McWilliams | first2=Donald | last2=Siegel | date=6 April 2000 | journal=Strategic Management Journal | volume=21 | number=5 | pages=603–609 | doi=10.1002/(SICI)1097-0266(200005)21:5<603::AID-SMJ101>3.0.CO;2-3 | url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1097-0266(200005)21:5%3C603::AID-SMJ101%3E3.0.CO;2-3/abstract }}</ref> Critics<ref name="IntroBusinessLaw2009">{{cite book | title=Introduction to Business Law | publisher=Cengage Learning |first1=Jeffrey F. |last1=Beatty | first2=Susan S. | last2=Samuelson | year=2009 }}</ref><ref name="reviewmisguidedCSR">{{cite journal |url = http://www.cfr.org/international-law/review-misguided-virtue-false-notions-corporate-social-responsibility/p4466 |title = Review of Misguided Virtue: False Notions of Corporate Social Responsibility |first = Matthew J. |last = Rosenberg |date = 1 April 2002 |journal = International Affairs |access-date = 2013-04-26 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130529225253/http://www.cfr.org/international-law/review-misguided-virtue-false-notions-corporate-social-responsibility/p4466 |archive-date = 2013-05-29 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> questioned the "lofty" and sometimes "unrealistic expectations" in CSR.<ref name="misguidedCSR">{{cite book | first=David | last=Henderson | title=Misguided Virtue: False Notions of Corporate Social Responsibility | publisher=Institute of Economic Affairs | year=2001 | page=171 | isbn=0-255-365101 }}</ref> or that CSR is merely [[Display window|window-dressing]], or an attempt to pre-empt the role of governments as a watchdog over powerful [[multinational corporations]]. In line with this critical perspective, political and sociological [[New institutionalism|institutionalists]] became interested in CSR in the context of theories of [[globalization]], [[neoliberalism]] and [[late capitalism]]. Some institutionalists viewed CSR as a form of capitalist legitimacy and in particular point out that what began as a social movement against uninhibited [[corporate power]] was transformed by corporations into a 'business model' and a 'risk management' device, often with questionable results.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1540-5893.2011.00439.x| title = Socially Responsible Private Regulation: World-Culture or World-Capitalism?| journal = Law & Society Review| volume = 45| issue = 2| pages = 313–336| year = 2011| last1 = Shamir | first1 = R. }}</ref>
CSR is titled to aid an organization's mission as well as serve as a guide to what the company represents for its consumers. [[Business ethics]] is the part of [[applied ethics]] that examines ethical principles and moral or ethical problems that can arise in a business environment. [[ISO 26000]] is the recognized international standard for CSR. Public sector organizations (the United Nations for example) adhere to the [[triple bottom line]] (TBL). It is widely accepted that CSR adheres to similar principles, but with no formal act of legislation.
{{toclimit|3}}
== Definition ==
Since the 1960s,{{sfn |De George |2011}} corporate social responsibility has attracted attention from a range of businesses and stakeholders. A wide variety of definitions have been developed but with little consensus. Part of the problem with definitions has arisen because of the different interests represented. A business person may define CSR as a business strategy, an NGO activist may see it as 'greenwash' while a government official may see it as voluntary regulation."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Sheehy|first=Benedict|date=2015-10-01|title=Defining CSR: Problems and Solutions|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|language=en|volume=131|issue=3|pages=625–648|doi=10.1007/s10551-014-2281-x|issn=0167-4544}}</ref> In addition, disagreement about the definition will arise from the disciplinary approach."<ref name=":3" /> For example, while an economist might consider the director's discretion necessary for CSR to be implemented a risk of agency costs, a law academic may consider that discretion to be an appropriate expression of what the law demands from directors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sommer|first=A.A. Jr|date=1991|title=Whom should the corporation serve? the Berle Dodd debate revisited sixty years later|url=|journal=Delaware Journal of Corporate Law|volume=16|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sheehy|first=Benedict|date=2014|title=Anglo-American Directors' Legal Duties and CSR: Prohibited, Permitted or Prescribed?|url=|journal=Dalhousie Law Journal|volume=31|pages=345|via=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/dalholwj37&div=15&id=&page=}}</ref>
Corporate social responsibility has recently been defined by Sheehy as "international private business self-regulation."<ref name=":3" /> Sheehy examined a range of different disciplinary approaches to defining CSR. The definitions reviewed included the economic definition of "sacrificing profits," a management definition of "beyond compliance", institutionalist views of CSR as a "socio-political movement" and law's own focus on directors' duties. Further, Sheehy considered Carroll's widely used description of CSR as a pyramid of responsibilities, namely, economic, legal, ethical and philanthropic responsibilities.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carroll|first=Archie B.|date=July 1991|title=The pyramid of corporate social responsibility: Toward the moral management of organizational stakeholders|journal=Business Horizons|volume=34|issue=4|pages=39–48|doi=10.1016/0007-6813(91)90005-g|issn=0007-6813}}</ref> Importantly, while Carroll was not defining CSR but simply arguing for classification of activities, Sheehy developed a definition differently following the philosophy of science—the branch of philosophy used for defining phenomena.
Carroll 1991 extended corporate social responsibility from the traditional economic and legal responsibility to ethical and philanthropic responsibility in response to the rising concerns on ethical issues in businesses, .<ref>{{cite journal|last=Carroll|first=Archie B. |date=1991|title=The pyramid of corporate social responsibility: toward moral management of organizational stakeholders|url=|journal=Business Horizons|volume=34 |issue=4|pages=39–48|doi=10.1016/0007-6813(91)90005-g}}</ref> This view is reflected in the ''Business Dictionary'' which defines CSR as "A company's sense of responsibility towards the community and environment (both ecological and social) in which it operates. Companies express this citizenship (1) through their waste and pollution reduction processes, (2) by contributing educational and social programs and (3) by earning adequate returns on the employed resources."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/corporate-social-responsibility.html |title=Definition of CSR |accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref>
<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=Innovation and Transformation|last=Kaschny|first=Martin|publisher=Springer Verlag|year=2018|isbn=978-3-319-78523-3|location=Germany|pages=297, 298}}</ref>
<ref name=":4" />
== Consumer perspectives == {{Reduced pull quote|1=right |2=Businesses have changed when the public came to expect and require different behavior [...] I predict that in the future, just as in the past, changes in public attitudes will be essential for changes in businesses' environmental practices. |3=[[Jared Diamond]]|4="Big businesses and the environment"<ref>[[Jared Diamond]], ''[[Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Survive]]'', Penguin Books, 2011, chapter "Big businesses and the environment: different conditions, different outcomes", page 485 ({{ISBN|978-0-241-95868-1}}).</ref> }}
Most consumers agree that while achieving business targets, companies should engage in CSR efforts at the same time.{{sfn |Epstein-Reeves |2010}} Most consumers believe companies doing charity work will receive a positive response.{{sfn |Somerville |2013}} Somerville also found that consumers are loyal and willing to spend more on retailers that support charity. Consumers also believe that retailers selling local products will gain loyalty.{{sfn |Kardashian |2013}} Smith (2013)<ref>{{cite web |last=Smith |first=Nicola |title=Corporate social responsibility: Power to the people |url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/trends/corporate-social-responsibility-power-to-the-people/4006810.article |date=2013 |accessdate=28 April 2014}}</ref> shares the belief that marketing local products will gain consumer trust. However, environmental efforts are receiving negative views given the belief that this would affect customer service.{{sfn |Kardashian |2013}} Oppewal et al. (2006) found that not all CSR activities are attractive to consumers.{{sfn |Oppewal |Alexander |Sulliwan |2006}} They recommended that retailers focus on one activity.{{sfn |Smith |Lopez |Read |2010}} Becker-Olsen (2006)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Becker-Olsen |first=K. L. |author2=Cudmore B. A. |author3=Hill R. P. |title=The impact of perceived corporate social responsibility on consumer behaviour |journal=Journal of Business Research}}</ref> found that if the social initiative done by the company is not aligned with other company goals it will have a negative impact. Mohr et al. (2001)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mohr |first=L. A. |author2=Webb D. J. and Harris K. E. |title=Do Consumers Expect Companies to be Socially Responsible? The Impact of Corporate Social Responsibility on Buying Behavior |journal=Journal of Consumer Affairs |volume=35 |series=1}}</ref> and Groza et al. (2011)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Groza |first=M. D. |author2=Pronschinske M. R. |author3=Walker M. |title=Perceived Organizational Motives and Consumer Responses to Proactive and Reactive CSR. |journal=Journal of Business Ethics |volume=102 |issue=4}}</ref> also emphasise the importance of reaching the consumer.
== Approaches ==
[[File:CSR framework - value1.jpg|upright=2|thumb |CSR Approaches]] Some commentators have identified a difference between the Canadian (Montreal school of CSR), the [[Continental Europe]]an and the [[Anglosphere|Anglo-Saxon]] approaches to CSR.<ref>{{cite book |url = http://www.business.uiuc.edu/aguilera/pdf/Williams%20Aguilera%20OUPfinal%20dec%202006.pdf |title = The Oxford Handbook of Corporate Social Responsibility |chapter = Corporate Social Responsibility in a Comparative Perspective |last = Saether |first = Kim T. |first2 = Ruth V. |last2 = Aguilera |editor = Crane, A. |year = 2008 |publisher = Oxford University Press |isbn = 0-19-921159-0 |format = PDF |display-editors = etal |access-date = 2008-03-06 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090327090956/http://www.business.uiuc.edu/aguilera/pdf/Williams%20Aguilera%20OUPfinal%20dec%202006.pdf |archive-date = 2009-03-27 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> It is said that for Chinese consumers,<ref>{{cite web|author=Maverlinn and Vermander, B. |title=Corporate Social Responsibility in China: A Vision, an Assessment and a Blueprint, World Scientific |year=2013 |url=http://www.sjapc.net/content/corporate-social-responsibility-china}}</ref> a socially responsible company makes safe, high-quality products; for Germans it provides secure employment; in South Africa it makes a positive contribution to social needs such as health care and education.<ref>{{cite book |last=Knox |first=Simon |title=Corporate Social Responsibility and Business Decision Making |work=Spiritual Motivation: New Thinking for Business and Management |editor1-last=Ramsden |editor1-first=J.J. |editor2-last=Aida |editor2-first=S. and |editor3-last=Kakabadse |editor3-first=A |location=Basingstoke: |publisher= Palgrave Macmillan |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-230-54291-4}}</ref> And even within Europe the discussion about CSR is very heterogeneous.{{sfn |Habisch |Jonker |Wagner |Schmidpeter |2005}}
A more common approach to CSR is corporate [[philanthropy]]. This includes monetary donations and aid given to nonprofit organizations and communities. Donations are made in areas such as the arts, education, housing, health, social welfare and the environment, among others, but excluding political contributions and commercial event sponsorship.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tilcsik |first=András |last2=Marquis |first2=Christopher |title=Punctuated Generosity: How Mega-events and Natural Disasters Affect Corporate Philanthropy in U.S. Communities |journal=Administrative Science Quarterly |date=1 February 2013 |volume=58 |issue=1 |pages=111–148 |url= https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2028982 |publisher=Social Science Research Network |accessdate=19 January 2018 |doi=10.1177/0001839213475800}}</ref>
Another approach to CSR is to incorporate the CSR strategy directly into operations, such as procurement of [[Fair trade|Fair Trade]] tea and coffee.
[[Creating shared value]] or CSV is based on the idea that corporate success and social welfare are interdependent. A business needs a healthy, educated workforce, sustainable resources and adept government to compete effectively. For society to thrive, profitable and competitive businesses must be developed and supported to create income, wealth, tax revenues and philanthropy. The Harvard Business Review article ''Strategy & Society: The Link between Competitive Advantage and Corporate Social Responsibility'' provided examples of companies that have developed deep linkages between their business strategies and CSR.{{sfn |Porter |Kramer |2006}} CSV acknowledges trade-offs between short-term profitability and social or environmental goals, but emphasizes the opportunities for competitive advantage from building a social value proposition into corporate strategy. CSV gives the impression that only two stakeholders are important - shareholders and consumers.
Many companies employ [[benchmarking]] to assess their CSR policy, implementation and effectiveness. Benchmarking involves reviewing competitor initiatives, as well as measuring and evaluating the impact that those policies have on society and the environment, and how others perceive competitor CSR strategy.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hoessle|first= Ulrike|title= Ten Steps Toward a Sustainable Business (WWS Series 1 Seattle 2013)| isbn =978-0-9898270-0-3|url= http://www.wwsworldwide.com}}</ref>
=== Cost-benefit analysis ===
In competitive markets [[cost-benefit analysis]] of CSR initiatives can be examined using a [[resource-based view]] (RBV). According to Barney (1990), "formulation of the RBV, sustainable competitive advantage requires that resources be valuable (V), rare (R), inimitable (I) and non-substitutable (S)."<ref name=BarneyRBV> {{cite journal | doi = 10.1177/014920639101700108| title = Firm Resources and Sustained Competitive Advantage| journal = Journal of Management| volume = 17| pages = 99–120| year = 1991| last1 = Barney | first1 = J.}}</ref><ref name=RBV>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1002/smj.4250050207| title = A resource-based view of the firm| journal = Strategic Management Journal| volume = 5| issue = 2| pages = 171–180| year = 1984| last1 = Wernerfelt | first1 = B. }}</ref> A firm introducing a CSR-based strategy might only sustain high returns on their investment if their CSR-based strategy could not be copied (I). However, should competitors imitate such a strategy, that might increase overall social benefits. Firms that choose CSR for strategic financial gain are also acting responsibly.
RBV presumes that firms are bundles of heterogeneous resources and capabilities that are imperfectly mobile across firms. This imperfect mobility can produce competitive advantages for firms that acquire immobile resources. McWilliams and Siegel (2001) examined CSR activities and attributes as a differentiation strategy. They concluded that managers can determine the appropriate level of investment in CSR by conducting cost benefit analysis in the same way that they analyze other investments. Reinhardt (1998) found that a firm engaging in a CSR-based strategy could only sustain an abnormal return if it could prevent competitors from imitating its strategy.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Siegel |first=Donald S. |year=2009 |title=Green Management Matters Only If It Yields More Green: An Economic/Strategic Perspective |url=http://econpapers.repec.org/paper/jmswpaper/8.htm |publisher= Academy of Management Perspectives |volume= 23 |issue=3 |pages=5–16}}</ref>
Moreover, when it comes to cost benefit analysis, you should look at Waddock and Graves (1997), who showed that corporate social performance was positively linked to financial performance, meaning that the benefit of being socially responsible outweigh the costs. McWilliams and Siegel (2000) noted that Waddock and Graves hadn’t taken innovation into account, that companies that did CSR were also very innovative, and that the innovation drove financial performance, not CSR. Hull and Rothenberg (2007) then found that when companies are not innovative, a history of CSR does in fact help financial performance. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hull|first=Clyde|last2=ROTHENBERG|first2=SANDRA|date=February 2008|title=Firm Performance: The Interactions of Corporate Social Performance with Innovation and Industry Differentiation|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/bd04/2027709bca590b8c2b68bf74be39148f64d9.pdf|journal=Strategic Management Journal|volume=Strat. Mgmt. J. , 29 : 781 – 789|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Scope ==
Initially, CSR emphasized the official behaviour of individual firms. Later, it expanded to include supplier behaviour and the uses to which products were put and how they were disposed of after they lost value.
=== Supply chain === In the 21st century, corporate social responsibility in the supply chain has attracted attention from businesses and stakeholders. Corporations' supply chain is the process by which several organizations including suppliers, customers and logistics providers work together to provide a value package of products and services to the end user, who is the customer.<ref>{{cite book|title=Designing and managing the supply chain|last=Simchi-Levi;kaminsky, D.P|first=Levi;D., P|publisher=McGraw Hill/Irwin|year=2002|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref>
Corporate social irresponsibility in the supply chain has greatly affected the reputation of companies, leading to a lot of cost to solve the problems. For instance, incidents like the [[2013 Savar building collapse]], which killed over 1000 people, pushed companies to consider the impacts of their operations on society and environment. On the other side, the horse meat scandal of 2013 in the United Kingdom affected many food retailers, including Tesco, the largest retailer in the United Kingdom,<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/foodanddrinknews/9891296/Horsemeat-scandal-supermarkets-have-failed-to-check-meat-suppliers-MPs-told.html |title=Horsemeat scandal: supermarkets have failed to check meat suppliers, MPs told|first=Rowena|last=Mason|date=24 February 2013|publisher=|accessdate=19 January 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}}</ref> leading to the dismissal of the supplier. Corporate social irresponsibility from both the suppliers and the retailers has greatly affected the stakeholders who lost trust for the affected business entities, and despite the fact that sometimes it's not directly undertaken by the companies, they become accountable to the stakeholders. These surrounding issues have prompted [[supply chain management]] to consider the corporate social responsibility context. Wieland and Handfield (2013) suggested that companies need to include social responsibility in their reviews of component quality. They highlighted the use of technology in improving visibility across the [[supply chain]].<ref>{{cite journal |first=Andreas |last=Wieland |first2=Robert B. |last2=Handfield |year=2013 |url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bth&AN=90423931&site=ehost-live |title=The Socially Responsible Supply Chain: An Imperative for Global Corporations |journal=Supply Chain Management Review |volume= 17 |issue= 5 |pages=22–29}}</ref>
===Corporate social initiatives=== Corporate social responsibility includes six types of corporate social initiatives:<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Nancy|last2=Kotler|first2=Philip|title=Corporate social responsibility doing the most good for your company and your cause|date=2013|publisher=Wiley|location=Hoboken, N.J.|isbn=9781118045770}}</ref> * Corporate philanthropy: company donations to charity, including cash, goods, and services, sometimes via a corporate foundation * Community volunteering: company-organized volunteer activities, sometimes while an employee receives pay for pro-bono work on behalf of a non-profit organization * Socially-responsible business practices: ethically produced products which appeal to a customer segment * Cause promotions: company-funded advocacy campaigns * Cause-related marketing: donations to charity based on product sales * Corporate social marketing: company-funded behavior-change campaigns
All six of the corporate initiatives are forms of corporate citizenship. However, only some of these CSR activities rise to the level of [[cause marketing]], defined as "a type of corporate social responsibility (CSR) in which a company's promotional campaign has the dual purpose of increasing profitability while bettering society."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Organ|first1=Michael|title=Cause Marketing — Definition|url=https://causemarketing.com/research/cause-marketing-definition/|accessdate=June 14, 2017}}</ref>
Companies generally do not have a [[profit motive]] when participating in corporate philanthropy and community volunteering. On the other hand, the remaining corporate social initiatives can be examples of cause marketing, in which there is both a societal interest and profit motive.
== Implementation ==
CSR may be based within the [[human resources]], [[business development]] or [[public relations]] departments of an organisation,<ref name=careers>{{cite web |url= http://www.careers.ed.ac.uk/STUDENTS/Careers/Corporate%20Social%20Responsibility%20and%20Ethical%20Careers.html |title= Corporate Social Responsibility and Ethical Careers |publisher=University of Edinburgh Careers Service |accessdate= 2008-03-07 }}</ref> or may be a separate unit reporting to the [[CEO]] or the [[board of directors]].
=== Engagement plan ===
An engagement plan can assist in reaching a desired audience. A corporate social responsibility individual or team plans the [[goal]]s and [[Goal|objectives]] of the organization. As with any corporate activity, a defined budget demonstrates commitment and scales the program's relative importance.
=== Accounting, auditing and reporting === {{Main |Social accounting}}
[[Social accounting]] is the communication of social and environmental effects of a company's economic actions to particular interest groups within society and to society at large.<ref>{{cite book | doi = 10.1007/978-3-642-02630-0_2| chapter = Corporate Responsibility, Accounting and Accountants| title = Professionals' Perspectives of Corporate Social Responsibility| pages = 11–32| year = 2009| last1 = Tilt | first1 = C. A. | isbn = 978-3-642-02629-4}}</ref>
Social accounting emphasizes the notion of corporate [[accountability]]. Crowther defines social accounting as "an approach to reporting a firm's activities which stresses the need for the identification of socially relevant behavior, the determination of those to whom the company is accountable for its social performance and the development of appropriate measures and reporting techniques."<ref name="Crowther2000">{{cite book |first=David |last=Crowther |title=Social and Environmental Accounting |url={{google books |plainurl=y |id=QLYCAAAACAAJ |p=20}} |year=2000 |publisher=Financial Times/Prentice Hall |isbn=978-0-273-65092-8 |p=20}}</ref> Reporting guidelines and standards serve as frameworks for social accounting, auditing and reporting: * [[AccountAbility (Institute of Social and Ethical AccountAbility)|AccountAbility]]'s [[AccountAbility (Institute of Social and Ethical AccountAbility)#AA1000 Series of Standards|AA1000]] standard, based on [[John Elkington (business author)|John Elkington]]'s [[triple bottom line]] (3BL) reporting * The Prince's Accounting for Sustainability Project's Connected Reporting Framework<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.accountingforsustainability.org/output/page171.asp | title=Connected Reporting in Practice: a consolidated case study | accessdate=August 19, 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923095823/http://www.accountingforsustainability.org/output/page171.asp | archivedate=September 23, 2010}}</ref> * The [[Fair Labor Association]] conducts audits based on its Workplace Code of Conduct and posts audit results on the FLA website. * The [[Fair Wear Foundation]] verifies labour conditions in companies' supply chains, using interdisciplinary auditing teams. * [[Global Reporting Initiative]]'s [[Sustainability Reporting]] Guidelines * [[Economy for the Common Good]]'s Common Good Balance Sheet<ref>{{cite web | url=http://economia-del-bene-comune.it/en/content/creating-common-good-balance-sheet | title=Creating a Common Good Balance Sheet | accessdate=August 19, 2016 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426095936/http://economia-del-bene-comune.it/en/content/creating-common-good-balance-sheet | archivedate=April 26, 2013 | deadurl=y | publisher=Economy for the Common Good}}</ref> * GoodCorporation's standard<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.goodcorporation.com/PDF/standard_2007.pdf | title=The GoodCorporation Standard | publisher=GoodCorporation | date=July 2010 | accessdate=August 19, 2016}}</ref> developed in association with the Institute of Business Ethics * Synergy Codethic 26000<ref>{{cite web |author=Synergy-gss |url=http://www.synergy-gss.com/SynergyStandards/Codethic26000.php |title=Synergy |publisher=Synergy-gss.com |accessdate=2013-04-22}}</ref> Social Responsibility and Sustainability Commitment Management System (SRSCMS) Requirements—Ethical Business Best Practices of Organizations—the necessary management system elements to obtain a certifiable ethical commitment management system. The standard scheme has been build around ISO 26000 and UNCTAD Guidance on Good Practices in Corporate Governance. The standard is applicable by any type of organization.; * [[Earthcheck]] Certification / Standard * Social Accountability International's [[SA8000]] standard * [[Standard Ethics Aei]] guidelines * The [[ISO 14000]] environmental management standard * The [[United Nations Global Compact]] requires companies to communicate on their progress<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unglobalcompact.org/COP|title=Reporting - UN Global Compact|website=www.unglobalcompact.org|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> (or to produce a Communication on Progress, COP), and to describe the company's implementation of the Compact's ten universal principles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unglobalcompact.org/docs/communication_on_progress/COP_Policy_Feb11.pdf|title=United Nations Global Compact|publisher=|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> * The [[United Nations]] Intergovernmental Working Group of Experts on International Standards of Accounting and Reporting (ISAR) provides voluntary technical guidance on eco-efficiency indicators,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unctad.org/en/docs/iteipc20037_en.pdf|title=ITEIPC 20037|publisher=|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> corporate responsibility reporting,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unctad.org/en/docs/iteteb20076_en.pdf|title=ITETEB 20076|publisher=|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> and corporate governance disclosure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unctad.org/en/docs/iteteb20063_en.pdf|title=ITETEB 20063|publisher=|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> * The [[FTSE Group]] publishes the [[FTSE4Good Index]], an evaluation of CSR performance of companies. * [[EthicalQuote|EthicalQuote (CEQ)]] tracks reputation of the world's largest companies on Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG), Corporate Social Responsibility, [[ethics]] and sustainability. * The [[Islamic Reporting Initiative|Islamic Reporting Initiative (IRI)]] is a [[Nonprofit organization|not-for-profit organization]] which leads the creation of the IRI framework; the guiding [[Integrated reporting|integrated]] CSR reporting framework based on [[Five Pillars of Islam|Islamic principles and values]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saudigazette.com.sa/saudi-arabia/philanthropy-csr-and-economic-growth/|title=Philanthropy, CSR and economic growth|author=Ajaz Ali|work=Saudi Gazette}}</ref>
In nations such as France, legal requirements for social accounting, auditing and reporting exist, though international or national agreement on meaningful measurements of social and environmental performance has not been achieved. Many companies produce externally audited annual reports that cover [[Sustainable Development]] and CSR issues ("Triple Bottom Line Reports"), but the reports vary widely in format, style, and [[evaluation]] [[methodology]] (even within the same industry). Critics dismiss these reports as lip service, citing examples such as [[Enron]]'s yearly "Corporate Responsibility Annual Report" and tobacco companies' social reports.
In South Africa, as of June 2010, all companies listed on the [[Johannesburg Stock Exchange]] (JSE) were required to produce an [[Integrated reporting|integrated report]] in place of an annual financial report and sustainability report.<ref>{{cite pr |url= https://www.saica.co.za/tabid/695/itemid/2344/language/en-ZA/An-integrated-report-is-a-new-requirement-for-list.aspx |title=News Articles and Press & media releases |publisher=South African Institute of Chartered Accountants |date=2010-03-01 |accessdate=2013-04-22}}</ref> An integrated report reviews environmental, social and economic performance alongside financial performance. This requirement was implemented in the absence of formal or legal standards. An Integrated Reporting Committee (IRC) was established to issue guidelines for good practice.
One of the reputable institutions that capital markets turn to for credible sustainability reports is the [[Carbon Disclosure Project]], or CDP.<ref>[http://info.esg.adec-innovations.com/blog/bid/311299/the-benefit-of-corporate-social-responsibility-csr-reporting The Benefit of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) Reporting]</ref>
=== Verification === Corporate social responsibility and its resulting reports and efforts should be verified by the consumer of the goods and services.<ref>{{cite web|title=Verifying Delivery of Sustainable Products and Services - GSA Sustainable Facilities Tool |url=https://sftool.gov/plan/541/verifying-delivery-sustainable-products-services |publisher=U.S. General Services Administration |accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref> The accounting, auditing and reporting resources provide a foundation for consumers to verify that their products are [[Social sustainability|socially sustainable]]. Due to an increased awareness of the need for CSR, many industries have their own verification resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sftool.gov/plan/542/resources-verifying-sustainable-products |title=Resources for Verifying Sustainable Products - GSA Sustainable Facilities Tool |publisher=U.S. General Services Administration |access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref> The include organizations like the [[Forest Stewardship Council]] (paper and forest products), [http://www.cocoainitiative.org/ International Cocoa Initiative], and [[Kimberley Process Certification Scheme|Kimberly Process]] (diamonds). The United Nations also provides frameworks not only for verification, but for reporting of human rights violations in corporate supply chains.
=== Ethics training ===
The rise of ethics training inside corporations, some of it required by government regulation, has helped CSR to spread. The aim of such training is to help employees make ethical decisions when the answers are unclear.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tullberg |first1=J. |last2=Tullberg |first2=S. |year=1996 |title=On Human Altruism: The Discrepancy between Normative and Factual Conclusions |journal=Oikos |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=327–329 |publisher= |doi= 10.2307/3546259 |jstor=3546259}}</ref> The most direct benefit is reducing the likelihood of "dirty hands",{{sfn |Grace |Cohen |2004}} fines and damaged reputations for breaching laws or moral norms. Organizations see increased employee loyalty and pride in the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shrm.org/publications/hrmagazine/editorialcontent/pages/0907agenda_training.aspx|title=Supporting Ethical Employees|last=Thilmany|first=Jean|date=2007|website=HR Magazine|publisher=Society for Human Resource Management|access-date=2016-04-04}}</ref>
